title: Example Workflow
text: use specification illustrative purposes . specification contains following four modules/equations: first two equations simply accounting identities. third equation models imports function final consumption expenditure households gross capital formation. fourth equation models carbon emissions combustion activities, includes energy industries, manufacturing construction, transport, combustion activities sectors.regressors number heating degree days, harmonised index consumer prices energy, total gross value added.
code: specification <- dplyr::tibble(     type = c(       "d",       "d",       "n",       "n"     ),     dependent = c(       "StatDiscrep",       "TOTS",       "Import",       "EmiCO2Combustion"     ),     independent = c(       "TOTS - FinConsExpHH - FinConsExpGov - GCapitalForm - Export",       "GValueAdd + Import",       "FinConsExpHH + GCapitalForm",       "HDD + HICP_Energy + GValueAdd"     )   ) print(specification) #> # A tibble: 4 × 3 #>   type  dependent        independent                                             #>   <chr> <chr>            <chr>                                                   #> 1 d     StatDiscrep      TOTS - FinConsExpHH - FinConsExpGov - GCapitalForm - E… #> 2 d     TOTS             GValueAdd + Import                                      #> 3 n     Import           FinConsExpHH + GCapitalForm                             #> 4 n     EmiCO2Combustion HDD + HICP_Energy + GValueAdd

text: differentiate data can obtained principle versus obtained actually specific model run. example, variable available Eurostat can downloaded Eurostat might saved locally previous model run. order save time, user might prefer local data used rather re-downloading data. dictionary specifies data different variables can obtained principle. column dict$database may take one four different values: eurostat variable available Eurostat using eurostat::get_eurostat(), edgar (emissions) variable available EDGAR using link, local variable available two sources therefore provided local file user directory inputdata_directory. directory searched .rds, .csv, .xlsx files, opens consecutively, searches variable. NA variable constructed identity/definition argument primary_source main function run_model() governs data actually obtained model run. Data can principle downloaded eurostat edgar can also loaded locally saved manually user using save_to_disk argument run_model() previous model run. argument primary_source can take either value "download" "local", governs whether download local input takes precedence eurostat edgar variables. gives rise following combinations obtaining data: variables dictionary$database == "local" always searched among local files inputdata_directory error raised found argument primary_source == "download" first downloads variables (potentially updating values) searches local directory variables obtained way (e.g. problems download) argument primary_source == "local" first searches local directory downloads variables found locally , use variables can principle obtained either Eurostat EDGAR use local file example-workflow-data.rds save time compiling vignette. avoid downloading variables , specify primary_source == "local" provide inputdata_directory path local directory calling run_model().
code: vars <- c("StatDiscrep", "TOTS", "Import", "EmiCO2Combustion", "FinConsExpHH",           "FinConsExpGov", "GCapitalForm", "Export", "GValueAdd", "HDD",           "HICP_Energy") dict %>%    filter(model_varname %in% vars) %>%    pull(database) #>  [1] NA         "eurostat" "eurostat" "eurostat" "eurostat" "eurostat" #>  [7] "eurostat" "eurostat" "eurostat" "eurostat" "edgar"

title: Example Workflow
text: now ready run model obtain "osem" object.  quiet output, get information estimation. told local files used, namely file "example-workflow-data.rds", can found working directory "." vignette created. Next, obtain warning panel unbalanced, means “ragged edges” cause 20% data discarded limiting sample time periods available variables. Finally, estimation begins. order modules determined related , starting modules depend exogenous (unmodelled) variables gradually estimating modules order avoid reverse dependencies.
code: model <- run_model(specification = specification,                    dictionary = dict,                    inputdata_directory = NULL,                    primary_source = "local",                    save_to_disk = "./Downloaded_Input.xlsx",                    present = FALSE,                    quiet = FALSE,                     plot = FALSE) class(model) plot(model)

text: Now, can look model results.

title: Example Workflow
text: different modules stored model$module_collection, tibble stores datasets, independent dependent variables, model arguments, model "isat" object. example, taking closer look estimated module carbon emissions combustion activities: find number heating degree days (HDD) gross value added (GValueAdd) significant, gets model selection dropped harmonised consumer price index energy. gross value added heating degree days positive coefficient meaning increase emissions, expect. diagnostic tests autocorrelation autoregressive conditional heteroskedasticity pass.
code: # extract the isat model object co2module <- model$module_collection %>%    filter(dependent == "EmiCO2Combustion") %>%    pull(model) %>%    pluck(1) class(co2module) #> [1] "isat" # inspect the estimated equation print(co2module) #>  #> Date: Mon Jun 30 13:44:46 2025  #> Dependent var.: ln.EmiCO2Combustion  #> Method: Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) #> Variance-Covariance: Ordinary  #> No. of observations (mean eq.): 105  #> Sample: 1996-01-01 to 2022-01-01  #>  #> SPECIFIC mean equation: #>  #>                      coef   std.error   t-stat   p-value     #> mconst        11.98154443  0.09154820 130.8769 < 2.2e-16 *** #> trend         -0.00207087  0.00011991 -17.2697 < 2.2e-16 *** #> ln.HDD         0.06430458  0.01245560   5.1627 1.295e-06 *** #> q_2           -0.21223350  0.01639718 -12.9433 < 2.2e-16 *** #> q_3           -0.23504358  0.03143830  -7.4763 3.419e-11 *** #> q_4           -0.04575356  0.00851226  -5.3750 5.274e-07 *** #> sis2018-10-01 -0.07541015  0.01466713  -5.1414 1.416e-06 *** #> sis2020-01-01 -0.05082377  0.01647038  -3.0858  0.002646 **  #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #>  #> Diagnostics and fit: #>  #>                     Chi-sq df p-value   #> Ljung-Box AR(1)   3.078307  1 0.07934 . #> Ljung-Box ARCH(1) 0.006605  1 0.93523   #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #>                            #> SE of regression   0.02940 #> R-squared          0.97703 #> Log-lik.(n=105)  225.33551

text: can show relationship different modules using network() function. node represents module different colours represent whether variable given definition/identity, whether modelled endogenous variable depending models, whether exogenous variable input models. solid line arrow means variable retained model selection, dashed arrow means variable dropped model selection. code: network(model)

title: Example Workflow
text: can use model forecast variables modules. works definition/identity modules endogenous modules. user can either provide future values exogenous variables (e.g. corresponding certain scenario assumptions) use automatic AR models forecast future values exogenous variables. specify paths exogenous regressors, output informs us AR(4) processes used project paths. function returns object class "osem.forecast", can also plotted.
code: forecast <- forecast_model(model = model,                            exog_predictions = NULL,                            plot = FALSE) #> No exogenous values provided. Model will forecast the exogenous values with an AR4 process (incl. Q dummies, IIS and SIS w 't.pval = 0.001'). #> Alternative is exog_fill_method = 'last'. class(forecast) #> [1] "osem.forecast" plot(forecast)

title: Example Workflow
text: obtain overview diagnostic results endogenous module, can use command diagnostics_model(). avoids look "isat" model objects manually. diagnostics pass modules: neither evidence autocorrelated errors autoregressive conditional heteroskedasticity. output also shows many impulse indicators (representing outliers) step indicators (representing structural breaks mean) retained module, absolute share observations.

title: Adding a new variable to the Dictionary
text: example add new variable Dictionary:
code: # Add a new row to 'dict', which is an element of the osem package dict %>%    bind_rows(tibble(     model_varname = "IndProd", # this is free to choose but must be unique     full_name = "An index of Industrial Production",     database  = "eurostat",     variable_code = "PRD", # in this case use the bt_indicator information here     dataset_id = "sts_inpr_q",     var_col = "indic_bt", # here we specify what the column with the variables is called     freq = "q", # for quarterly data, 'm' would be monthly     geo = "AT",     unit = "I15", # for index of 2015 = 100     s_adj = "NSA", # not seasonally adjusted     nace_r2 = "B-D")) -> new_dict  # now use the new_dict in run_model

what: Some general remarks about the Dictionary
title: Adding a new variable to the Dictionary
text: dictionary central store information used us “translate” difficult data codes useful variable names - also central us tell OSEM Model download. Let’s take look dictionary: words variables/columns dictionary: crucial columns nearly always needed/useful. : model_varname: Variable name model equations, must unique. full_name: Full name/description variable. Currently full use also columns: database: Name database. Internally implemented “eurostat” “edgar.” variable_code: Identifier variable applicable, e.g., Eurostat variable code. dataset_id: Identifier dataset variable available, e.g., Eurostat dataset code link file web. varied use : var_col: Name variable/column dataset. freq: Frequency variable dataset. “m” monthly, “q” quarterly. geo: ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 country code. unit: Eurostat unit variable measured, e.g., choose different measurements variable. s_adj: Eurostat seasonal adjustment . nace_r2: Eurostat identifier NACE Rev. 2 classification. ipcc_sector: EDGAR IPCC National Greenhouse Gas Inventories, see link. “TOTAL” official IPCC code internally interpreted use country totals. cpa2_1: Eurostat identifier Classification Products Activity (CPA). siec: Standard International Energy Product Classification, e.g., Eurostat.

title: Adding a new variable to the Dictionary
text: Firstly, head Eurostat find variable like add. data viewer options Eurostat, recommend using “Data Explorer” . good link get started: Eurostat Data Viewer Data Navigation Tree

title: Adding a new variable to the Dictionary
text: Now let’s assume want add form Industrial Production dataset (Link). head back data tree select quarterly dataset Industrial Production (sts_inpr_q):  Now let’s take closer look data features typically top screen:  already gives us something crucial: dataset identifier, case sts_inpr_q. corresponds column dataset_id Dictionary dict. find even detailed features dataset, click big encircled + e.g. next “Time” “Unit Measure”. gives us ability play around bit define custom dataset specific needs:  really window need focus quite bit. First , note different dimensions data encapsulated square brackets [ ], like time, indicator_bt, s_adj, relevant marked yellow:  identify correct data, now need click different dimensions make note want use. available types vary depending Eurostat data, variables relevant OSEM Model include: variable indicates specific variable name, like na_item indic_bt, depending Eurostat guidelines associated data collection method used. time geo: geography data belongs (see Glossary:Country codes - Statistics Explained (europa.eu) information format). unit: unit variable like €, tonnes, %, etc. (frequently also kind indices like I15 Index = 2015). corresponds unit column Dictionary dict. s_adj: Seasonal Adjustment, e.g. NSA refers “Seasonal Adjustment” Sometimes data consider can broken even , e.g. according sectors physical quantities (like different greenhouse gases). include example things like: nace_r2: column indicator indicates sector according Statistical classification economic activities European Community (NACE Revision 2) cp2_1: column indicator indicates Statistical classification products activity, 2.1 (CPA 2.1) siec: Standard International Energy Product Classification Based information , let’s say want add variable dataset sts_inpr_q: industrial production, spans NACE rev. 2 sectors sectors B D, Austria, using unit index set 2015 value seasonally adjusted.

title: Adding a new variable to the Dictionary
text: Given information, let’s try download first - using get_eurostat function {eurostat} package: Now let’s filter raw dataset data series need: looks quite good. can plot really quickly:
code: dat_raw <- get_eurostat(id = "sts_inpr_q") dat_raw %>%    filter(indic_bt == "PRD", # for industrial production variable          nace_r2 == "B-D", # to select all NACE rev 2 sectors in B, C, and D          s_adj == "NSA", # to get the raw, non-adjusted data          unit == "I15", # to get the 2015 Index          geo == "AT" # to get only the Austrian data          ) -> dat_AT dat_AT ggplot(dat_AT, aes(x = TIME_PERIOD, y = values, color = indic_bt)) +    geom_line(linewidth = 1) +       # add some styling   geom_hline(aes(yintercept = 0)) + # to get a line through 0   labs(title = "Industrial Production in Austria", x = NULL, y = "Industrial Production Index, 2015 = 100") +    theme_minimal(base_size = 15)+   theme(legend.position = "bottom")

what: Quickly run a small model to check if it works:
title: Adding a new variable to the Dictionary
text: can now put test extremely small model. construct model CO[2] Process Emissions Industry function Gas Electricity Prices well new measure Industrial Production: EmiCO2IndustryProcess=HICPGas+HICPElectricity+IndProdIdx EmiCO2IndustryProcess = HICP_{Gas} + HICP_{Electricity} + IndProdIdx specification run - type n denotes Definition therefore estimated: specification set , now run model using new_dict constructed earlier.  Let’s visualise model alongside forecast:
code: specification <- dplyr::tibble(   type = c(     "n"   ),   dependent = c(     "EmiCO2IndustryProcess"   ),   independent = c(     "HICP_Gas + HICP_Electricity + IndProdIdx"   ) ) specification #> # A tibble: 1 × 3 #>   type  dependent             independent                              #>   <chr> <chr>                 <chr>                                    #> 1 n     EmiCO2IndustryProcess HICP_Gas + HICP_Electricity + IndProdIdx model <- run_model(specification = specification,                    dictionary = new_dict,                     present = FALSE,                    quiet = TRUE,                    constrain.to.minimum.sample = FALSE) mod_fcast <- forecast_model(model, plot = FALSE) #> No exogenous values provided. Model will forecast the exogenous values with an AR4 process (incl. Q dummies, IIS and SIS w 't.pval = 0.001'). #> Alternative is exog_fill_method = 'last'. plot(mod_fcast)

Unclear what this is. Using Building Permits instead     "Export + LabCostService"   ))

code: model_forecast <- forecast_model(model_result, n.ahead = 10, exog_fill_method = "AR", plot = FALSE) #> No exogenous values provided. code: estimate_module(   clean_data,   dep_var_basename,   x_vars_basename,   use_logs = "both",   trend = TRUE,   ardl_or_ecm = "ardl",   max.ar = 4,   max.dl = 2,   saturation = c("IIS", "SIS"),   saturation.tpval = 0.01,   max.block.size = 20,   gets_selection = TRUE,   selection.tpval = 0.01,   keep,   pretest_steps,   quiet = FALSE )

title: Estimate the specific module using indicator saturation — estimate_module
text: clean_data input data.frame tibble. Must output clean_data() fit requirements. dep_var_basename character string name dependent variable contained clean_data() level form (.e. ln D front name). x_vars_basename character vector name(s) independent variable(s) contained clean_data() level form (.e. ln D front name). use_logs decide whether log variables. Must one '', 'y', 'x', 'none'. Default ''. trend Logical. determine whether trend added. Default TRUE. ardl_or_ecm Either 'ardl' 'ecm' determine whether estimate model Autoregressive Distributed Lag Function (ardl) Equilibrium Correction Model (ecm). max.ar Integer. maximum number lags use AR terms. well independent variables. max.dl Integer. maximum number lags use independent variables (distributed lags). saturation Carry Indicator Saturation using 'isat' function 'gets' package. Needs character vector string. Default 'c("IIS","SIS")' carry Impulse Indicator Saturation Step Indicator Saturation. possible values 'NULL' disable 'TIS' Trend Indicator Saturation. disabled, estimation carried using 'arx' function 'gets' package. saturation.tpval target p-value saturation methods (e.g. SIS IIS, see 'isat' function 'gets' package). Default 0.01. max.block.size Integer. Maximum size block variables selected , default = 20. gets_selection Logical. Whether general--specific selection using 'getsm' function 'gets' package done final saturation model. Default TRUE. selection.tpval Numeric. target p-value model selection methods (.e. general--specific modelling, see 'getsm' function 'gets' package). Default 0.01. keep Character. string used regex (grepl()) selection carried . argument therefore requires gets_selection = TRUE. Variables match character selected (see getsm details). pretest_steps Logical. Default FALSE. argument controls whether isat first run SIS isolation saturation methods added (IIS, TIS). can lead better results many IIS identified end estimation sample/forecast origin. TRUE isat first carried just SIS (activated using 'sis = TRUE'), SIS breaks pre-entered another isat estimation selected . isat runs, union model selection done using  gets. quiet Logical. messages forecast procedure suppressed?

title: Determine the number of Forecast Failures in Insample Forecasting — forecast_failure
code: specification <- dplyr::tibble(  type = c(    "n"  ),  dependent = c(    "FinConsExpHH"  ),  independent = c(    "FinConsExpGov + HICP_Gas"  ) )  set.seed(123) testdata <- dplyr::tibble(  time = seq.Date(from = as.Date("2005-01-01"),                  to = as.Date("2023-10-01"),                  by = "quarter"),  FinConsExpGov = rnorm(mean = 100, n = length(time)),  HICP_Gas = rnorm(mean = 200, n = length(time)),  FinConsExpHH  = 0.5 + 0.2*FinConsExpGov + 0.3 *    HICP_Gas + rnorm(length(time), mean = 0, sd = 0.2))  testdata <- tidyr::pivot_longer(testdata,                                cols = -time,                                names_to = "na_item",                                values_to = "values")  model <- run_model(specification = specification,                   dictionary = dict,                   inputdata_directory = testdata,                   primary_source = "local",                   present = FALSE,                   quiet = TRUE,                   saturation = "IIS")   insample_output <- forecast_insample(model, sample_share = 0.97) #> [1] "Model Run 1 up to 2023-04-01" #> [1] "Model Run 2 up to 2023-07-01" #> [1] "Model Run 3 up to 2023-10-01" #> [1] "Forecast 1 from 2023-04-01 to 2023-10-01" #> [1] "Forecast 2 from 2023-07-01 to 2023-10-01"  insample_output$forecast_failures #> # A tibble: 3 × 10 #>   time       na_item      values failure_all failure_95 failure_90 failure_50 #>   <date>     <chr>         <dbl> <chr>       <chr>      <chr>      <chr>      #> 1 2023-07-01 FinConsExpHH   80.5 Success     Success    Success    Success    #> 2 2023-10-01 FinConsExpHH   80.8 Success     Success    Success    Failure    #> 3 2023-10-01 FinConsExpHH   80.8 Success     Success    Success    Failure    #> # ℹ 3 more variables: start <date>, end <date>, method <chr>

title: Root Mean Squared Forecast Error — rmsfe
code: specification <- dplyr::tibble(  type = c(    "n"  ),  dependent = c(    "FinConsExpHH"  ),  independent = c(    "FinConsExpGov + HICP_Gas"  ) )  set.seed(123) testdata <- dplyr::tibble(  time = seq.Date(from = as.Date("2005-01-01"),                  to = as.Date("2023-10-01"),                  by = "quarter"),  FinConsExpGov = rnorm(mean = 100, n = length(time)),  HICP_Gas = rnorm(mean = 200, n = length(time)),  FinConsExpHH  = 0.5 + 0.2*FinConsExpGov + 0.3 *    HICP_Gas + rnorm(length(time), mean = 0, sd = 0.2))  testdata <- tidyr::pivot_longer(testdata,                                cols = -time,                                names_to = "na_item",                                values_to = "values")  model <- run_model(specification = specification,                   dictionary = dict,                   inputdata_directory = testdata,                   primary_source = "local",                   present = FALSE,                   quiet = TRUE,                   saturation = "IIS")   insample_output <- forecast_insample(model, sample_share = 0.97) #> [1] "Model Run 1 up to 2023-04-01" #> [1] "Model Run 2 up to 2023-07-01" #> [1] "Model Run 3 up to 2023-10-01" #> [1] "Forecast 1 from 2023-04-01 to 2023-10-01" #> [1] "Forecast 2 from 2023-07-01 to 2023-10-01"  insample_output$rmsfe #> # A tibble: 4 × 5 #>   na_item      rmsfe start      end        method #>   <chr>        <dbl> <date>     <date>     <chr>  #> 1 Total RMSFE  0.194 2023-04-01 2023-10-01 AR     #> 2 FinConsExpHH 0.194 2023-04-01 2023-10-01 AR     #> 3 Total RMSFE  0.247 2023-07-01 2023-10-01 AR     #> 4 FinConsExpHH 0.247 2023-07-01 2023-10-01 AR

Default 'c("IIS","SIS")' carry Impulse Indicator Saturation Step Indicator Saturation. possible values 'NULL' disable 'TIS' Trend Indicator Saturation. disabled, estimation carried using 'arx' function 'gets' package. saturation.tpval target p-value saturation methods (e.g. SIS IIS, see 'isat' function 'gets' package). Default 0.01. max.block.size Integer. Maximum size block variables selected , default = 20. pretest_steps Logical. Default FALSE. argument controls whether isat first run SIS isolation saturation methods added (IIS, TIS). can lead better results many IIS identified end estimation sample/forecast origin. TRUE isat first carried just SIS (activated using 'sis = TRUE'), SIS breaks pre-entered another isat estimation selected . isat runs, union model selection done using  gets. determine.blocksize Logical. Whether max.block.size needs determined.

title: Runs the OSEM model — run_model
code: run_model(   specification,   dictionary = NULL,   inputdata_directory = paste0(getwd(), "/data/raw"),   primary_source = c("download", "local"),   save_to_disk = NULL,   use_logs = "both",   trend = TRUE,   ardl_or_ecm = "ardl",   max.ar = 4,   max.dl = 4,   saturation = c("IIS", "SIS"),   saturation.tpval = 0.01,   max.block.size = 20,   gets_selection = TRUE,   selection.tpval = 0.01,   constrain.to.minimum.sample = TRUE,   keep = NULL,   pretest_steps = FALSE,   present = FALSE,   quiet = FALSE,   plot = TRUE )

title: Runs the OSEM model — run_model
text: specification tibble data.frame three columns. Column names must : 'type', 'dependent', 'independent'. column 'type' must contain row character either 'd' (Identity) 'n' (Definition - .e. estimated). column 'dependent' must contain LHS (Y variables) column named 'independent' containing RHS (x variables separated + -). dictionary tibble data.frame storing Eurostat variable code column 'eurostat_code' model variable name 'model_varname'. download == TRUE dictionary also requires column named 'dataset_id' stores Eurostat dataset id. NULL, default dictionary used. inputdata_directory path .rds input files data stored. Can NULL download == TRUE. primary_source string. Determines whether "download" "local" data loading takes precedence. save_to_disk path directory final dataset saved, including file name ending. saved NULL. use_logs decide whether log variables. Must one '', 'y', 'x', 'none'. Default ''. trend Logical. trend added? Default TRUE. ardl_or_ecm Either 'ardl' 'ecm' determine whether estimate model Autoregressive Distributed Lag Function (ardl) Equilibrium Correction Model (ecm). max.ar Integer. maximum number lags use AR terms. well independent variables. max.dl Integer. maximum number lags use independent variables (distributed lags). saturation Carry Indicator Saturation using 'isat' function 'gets' package. Needs character vector string. Default 'c("IIS","SIS")' carry Impulse Indicator Saturation Step Indicator Saturation. possible values 'NULL' disable 'TIS' Trend Indicator Saturation. disabled, estimation carried using 'arx' function 'gets' package. saturation.tpval target p-value saturation methods (e.g. SIS IIS, see 'isat' function 'gets' package). Default 0.01. max.block.size Integer. Maximum size block variables selected , default = 20. gets_selection Logical. Whether general--specific selection using 'getsm' function 'gets' package done final saturation model. Default TRUE. selection.tpval Numeric. target p-value model selection methods (.e. general--specific modelling, see 'getsm' function 'gets' package). Default 0.01. constrain..minimum.sample Logical. data series constrained minimum data series? Default TRUE. keep Character. string used regex (grepl()) selection carried . argument therefore requires gets_selection = TRUE. Variables match character selected (see getsm details). pretest_steps Logical. Default FALSE. argument controls whether isat first run SIS isolation saturation methods added (IIS, TIS). can lead better results many IIS identified end estimation sample/forecast origin. TRUE isat first carried just SIS (activated using 'sis = TRUE'), SIS breaks pre-entered another isat estimation selected . isat runs, union model selection done using  gets. present logical value whether final OSEM model output presented . quiet Logical default = FALSE. messages displayed? messages intended give information estimation data retrieval process. plot Logical default = TRUE. plots displayed?

title: Runs the OSEM model — run_model
text: object class osem, named list four elements: args named list storing user arguments OSEM model. module_order_eurostatvars original specification translated variable names Eurostat codes arranged order estimation. module_collection specification two added columns store model object module dataset used estimation, including fitted values dependent variable. full_data tibble data.frame containing complete original data OSEM model fitted values module.

title: Runs a module — run_module
text: Runs module two different ways depending whether module endogenously modelled endogenous identity/definition.

title: Runs a module — run_module
code: run_module(   module,   data,   classification,   use_logs = c("both", "y", "x"),   trend = TRUE,   ardl_or_ecm = "ardl",   max.ar = 4,   max.dl = 2,   saturation = c("IIS", "SIS"),   saturation.tpval = 0.01,   max.block.size = 20,   gets_selection = TRUE,   selection.tpval = 0.01,   opts_df,   keep,   pretest_steps,   quiet )

title: Runs a module — run_module
text: module row specification table. data tibble data.frame containing full data OSEM model. classification data.frame two columns: 'var' stores Eurostat variable code 'class' classification code (one "n", "d", "x") reflecting whether variable endogenous modelling, endogenous identity/definition, exogenous. returned classify_variables. use_logs decide whether log variables. Must one '', 'y', 'x', 'none'. Default ''. trend Logical. trend added? Default TRUE. ardl_or_ecm Either 'ardl' 'ecm' determine whether estimate model Autoregressive Distributed Lag Function (ardl) Equilibrium Correction Model (ecm). max.ar Integer. maximum number lags use AR terms. well independent variables. max.dl Integer. maximum number lags use independent variables (distributed lags). saturation Carry Indicator Saturation using 'isat' function 'gets' package. Needs character vector string. Default 'c("IIS","SIS")' carry Impulse Indicator Saturation Step Indicator Saturation. possible values 'NULL' disable 'TIS' Trend Indicator Saturation. disabled, estimation carried using 'arx' function 'gets' package. saturation.tpval target p-value saturation methods (e.g. SIS IIS, see 'isat' function 'gets' package). Default 0.01. max.block.size Integer. Maximum size block variables selected , default = 20. gets_selection Logical. Whether general--specific selection using 'getsm' function 'gets' package done final saturation model. Default TRUE. selection.tpval Numeric. target p-value model selection methods (.e. general--specific modelling, see 'getsm' function 'gets' package). Default 0.01. opts_df Internal object containing detailed options information individual modules. keep Character. string used regex (grepl()) selection carried . argument therefore requires gets_selection = TRUE. Variables match character selected (see getsm details). pretest_steps Logical. Default FALSE. argument controls whether isat first run SIS isolation saturation methods added (IIS, TIS). can lead better results many IIS identified end estimation sample/forecast origin. TRUE isat first carried just SIS (activated using 'sis = TRUE'), SIS breaks pre-entered another isat estimation selected . isat runs, union model selection done using  gets. quiet Logical. messages forecast procedure suppressed?

title: Runs a module — run_module
text: Returns list two named elements. model endogenously modeled modules (type == "n"), object class isat arx. identity/definition modules (type == "d"), NULL. data data (including transformations) used estimate model fitted values dependent variable.

title: Super Exogeneity (Parameter Invariance) Test — super.exogeneity
text: function tests super exogeneity (parameter invariance) model. Parameter invariance key component Super Exogeneity, first introduced Engle, Hendry, Richard (1983; Econometrica). test runs indicator saturation model independent variable present initial.model object - individual models called marginal models. outliers step-shifts detected using isat function gets package marginal models, indicators added initial model, called conditional model. pre-existing indicators initial model removed, otherwise power test reduced. conditional model used run linear regression obtain F-Stat statistic determine whether shocks detected marginal models affect conditional model.

title: Super Exogeneity (Parameter Invariance) Test — super.exogeneity
text: initial.model object class isat (.e. gets package) contains initial model saturation.tpval target p-value saturation methods (e.g. SIS IIS, see 'isat' function 'gets' package). Default 0.01. quiet Logical. messages forecast procedure suppressed?

title: Super Exogeneity (Parameter Invariance) Test — super.exogeneity
text: h-test object results super exogeneity test

title: Super Exogeneity (Parameter Invariance) Test — super.exogeneity
text: p-value desired level statistical significance (e.g. 0.05) indicate model super exogenous (.e. parameters variant).

title: Super Exogeneity (Parameter Invariance) Test — super.exogeneity
text: Engle, R. F., Hendry, D. F., & Richard, J. F. (1983). Exogeneity. Econometrica: Journal Econometric Society, 73-85. Engle, R. F., & Hendry, D. F. (1993). Testing superexogeneity invariance regression models. Journal Econometrics, 56(1-2), 119-139. Hendry, D. F., & Santos, C., 'Automatic Test Super Exogeneity', Bollerslev, T., Russell, J., & Watson, M. (Eds.). (2010). Volatility time series econometrics: essays honor Robert Engle. OUP oxford. Castle, J. L., Hendry, D. F., & Martinez, . B. (2017). Evaluating forecasts, narratives policy using test invariance. Econometrics, 5(3), 39.
